definition.content:
## Avi Vantage

This dashboard allows you to monitor the health of your AVI Vantage load balancers, their performance, and the traffic flowing through them.

For further reading on monitoring Avi Vantage, see:

- [Official Avi Vantage integration docs](https://docs.datadoghq.com/integrations/avi_vantage/)

Clone this template to make changes and add your own graphs and widgets.

The Avi Vantage Platform has 2 core components – Avi Service Engines and Avi Controller cluster

Avi Service Engines (SEs) handle all data plane operations within Avi Vantage by receiving and executing instructions from the Controller. The SEs perform load balancing and all client- and server-facing network interactions. It collects real-time application telemetry from application traffic flows.

The Avi Controller is the single point of management and control that serves as the “brain” of the entire Avi Vantage system and for high availability is typically deployed as a three-node cluster. As its name implies, the Controller implements the control plane. A single Avi Vantage deployment is managed from this Controller/cluster (identified by FQDN and/or cluster IP address), regardless of the number of applications being load balanced or the number of SEs required. 

See the [Avi documentation](https://avinetworks.com/docs/20.1/configuration-guide/applications/virtual-services/vs-health/) for more details on the computation of this score.

It is the Controller’s duty to place virtual services on SEs to load balance new applications or increase the capacity of running applications. Controllers continually exchange information securely with the SEs and with one another. The health of servers, client connection statistics, and client-request logs collected by the SEs are regularly offloaded to the Controllers, which share the work of processing the logs and aggregating analytics.

Service Engines are created within a group, which contains the definition of how the SEs should be sized, placed, and made highly available.

See the [Avi documentation](https://avinetworks.com/docs/latest/service-engine-group/ for more details on Service Engines.

A virtual service can be thought of as an IP address that Vantage is listening to, ready to receive requests. In a normal TCP/HTTP configuration, when a client connects to the virtual service address, Vantage processes the client connection or request against a list of settings, policies, and profiles, then sends valid client traffic to a back-end server that is listed as a member of the virtual service’s pool.

See the [Avi documentation](https://avinetworks.com/docs/latest/architectural-overview/applications/virtual-services/) for more details on virtual services.

Pools maintain the list of servers assigned to them and perform health monitoring, load balancing, persistence, and functions that involve Avi-Vantage-to-server interaction. A pool may only be used or referenced by only one virtual service at a time.

See the [Avi documentation](https://avinetworks.com/docs/latest/architectural-overview/applications/pools/) for more details on Pools.
